Substrate.Source.Formatted: Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research
Foot.Type.Source.Formatted: Superina and Loughry 2011 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred: methods unclear but is a likely possibility
Fermentation.Type.Notes: The extant relatives, armadillos, are insectivores and have simple sac stomachs. Some have suggested the same for glyptodonts (Bocherens et al. 2017), but how they could sustain their metabolism as herbivores without fermentation seems dubious. Bocherens et al. 2017 found that their isotopic values (for Doedicurus spp, Glyptodon spp, Glyptotherium) suggested either aquatic habitat or a high fermentation rate. Vizcaino et al. 2011 suggested that given the estimated low metabolic rate of Xenarthans but the relatively complex teeth of cingulates compared to sloths, that sloths have higher fermentation in digestive tract than glyptodonts. These animals were likely hindgut and likely hingut colon, since there are no large mammals that use caecums
Substrate.Notes: High isotopic values suggest aquatic diet, and ichnosites show presence in 1 marshland in South America (McDonald 2005)

Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology, 20(4), 743â€“754. https://doi.org/10.1671/0272-4634(2000)020[0743:VISMAM]2.0.CO;2
Substrate.Source.Formatted: Inferred from absence of evidence
Foot.Type.Source.Formatted: Superina and Loughry 2011 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred: methods unclear but is a likely possibility
Fermentation.Type.Notes: The extant relatives, armadillos, are insectivores and have simple sac stomachs. Some have suggested the same for glyptodonts (Bocherens et al. 2017), but how they could sustain their metabolism as herbivores without fermentation seems dubious. Bocherens et al. 2017 found that their isotopic values (for Doedicurus spp, Glyptodon spp, Glyptotherium) suggested either aquatic habitat or a high fermentation rate. Vizcaino et al. 2011 suggested that given the estimated low metabolic rate of Xenarthans but the relatively complex teeth of cingulates compared to sloths, that sloths have higher fermentation in digestive tract than glyptodonts. These animals were likely hindgut and likely hingut colon, since there are no large mammals that use caecums

Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred: methods unclear but is a likely possibility
Fermentation.Type.Notes: The extant relatives, armadillos, are insectivores and have simple sac stomachs. Some have suggested the same for glyptodonts (Bocherens et al. 2017), but how they could sustain their metabolism as herbivores without fermentation seems dubious. Bocherens et al. 2017 found that their isotopic values (for Doedicurus spp, Glyptodon spp, Glyptotherium) suggested either aquatic habitat or a high fermentation rate. Vizcaino et al. 2011 suggested that given the estimated low metabolic rate of Xenarthans but the relatively complex teeth of cingulates compared to sloths, that sloths have higher fermentation in digestive tract than glyptodonts. These animals were likely hindgut and likely hingut colon, since there are no large mammals that use caecums

Browsing.Grazing.Source.Formatted: Franca et al. 2015 Earth Science Reviews; Saarinen and Karme 2017 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Browsing.Grazing.Notes: Strong indication of grazing preference, but a mixed feeder in closed canopy environments; data only given for genus. Sclerocalyptus also reported (as a similar grazer with browse ability, but taxa is not in our taxonomy. Vizcaino et al. 2011 Ameghiniana found that Glyptdon was a selective feeder whereas the rest of the group were bulk feeders based on relative muzzle width, hypsodonty index, and dental occlusal surface area.
Browsing.Grazing.Source.Original: de Melo Franca, L., de Asevedo, L., Dantas, M. A. T., Bocchiglieri, A., Avilla, L. dos S., Lopes, R. P., & da Silva, J. L. L. (2015). Review of feeding ecology data of Late Pleistocene mammalian herbivores from South America and discussions on niche differentiation. Earth-Science Reviews, 140, 158â€“165. https://doi.org/10.1016/J.EARSCIREV.2014.10.006 ; ï»¿Saarinen, J., & Karme, A. (2017). Tooth wear and diets of extant and fossil xenarthrans (Mammalia, Xenarthra) â€“ Applying a new mesowear approach. Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology, 476, 42â€“54. https://doi.org/10.1016/J.PALAEO.2017.03.027
Substrate.Source.Formatted: Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research
Foot.Type.Source.Formatted: Superina and Loughry 2011 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred: methods unclear but is a likely possibility
Fermentation.Type.Notes: The extant relatives, armadillos, are insectivores and have simple sac stomachs. Some have suggested the same for glyptodonts (Bocherens et al. 2017), but how they could sustain their metabolism as herbivores without fermentation seems dubious. Bocherens et al. 2017 found that their isotopic values (for Doedicurus spp, Glyptodon spp, Glyptotherium) suggested either aquatic habitat or a high fermentation rate. Vizcaino et al. 2011 suggested that given the estimated low metabolic rate of Xenarthans but the relatively complex teeth of cingulates compared to sloths, that sloths have higher fermentation in digestive tract than glyptodonts. These animals were likely hindgut and likely hingut colon, since there are no large mammals that use caecums
Substrate.Notes: High isotopic values suggest aquatic diet, and ichnosites show presence in 1 marshland in South America (McDonald 2005)

Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from morphology - locking knees suggest feeding style akin to rhinos or horses
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 and 2016 claim, without a source, that this group were foregut fermenters. However, available morphological evidence indicates nonruminant bulk fermentation, which at this body size is likely hindgut colon
Substrate.Notes: Potentially aquatic hippo-like habits? There is debate. Also, occurrence in rainforest and open grassland
Foot.Type.Notes: Rhino/tapir like foot, probably supported by thick pad. Functionally digitigrade
Other.Notes: the outer borders of the symphysis in the lower jaw don't diverge anteriorly, and the incisor form a semicircular structure that protrude less than the incisors of Toxodon; the snout was cylindrical, instead of the broad hippo-like muzzle of Toxodon. The straight snout and the narrow lower incisors closely packed, suggest that this animal had a different feeding strategy compared to their southern relative, although the teeth of both genera was adapted to deal with abrasive food.

Foot.Type.Source.Formatted: Superina and Loughry 2011 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred: methods unclear but is a likely possibility
Fermentation.Type.Notes: The extant relatives, armadillos, are insectivores and have simple sac stomachs. Some have suggested the same for glyptodonts (Bocherens et al. 2017), but how they could sustain their metabolism as herbivores without fermentation seems dubious. Bocherens et al. 2017 found that their isotopic values (for Doedicurus spp, Glyptodon spp, Glyptotherium) suggested either aquatic habitat or a high fermentation rate. Vizcaino et al. 2011 suggested that given the estimated low metabolic rate of Xenarthans but the relatively complex teeth of cingulates compared to sloths, that sloths have higher fermentation in digestive tract than glyptodonts. These animals were likely hindgut and likely hingut colon, since there are no large mammals that use caecums

Diet and habitat definitions for Mexican glyptodonts from Cedral (San Luis PotosÃ_, MÃ©xico) based on stable isotope analysis. Geol. Mag, 149(1), 153â€“157. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0016756811000951
Substrate.Source.Formatted: Gillette and Ray 1981 Smithsonian Institution Press
Foot.Type.Source.Formatted: Superina and Loughry 2011 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred: methods unclear but is a likely possibility
Fermentation.Type.Notes: The extant relatives, armadillos, are insectivores and have simple sac stomachs. Some have suggested the same for glyptodonts (Bocherens et al. 2017), but how they could sustain their metabolism as herbivores without fermentation seems dubious. Bocherens et al. 2017 found that their isotopic values (for Doedicurus spp, Glyptodon spp, Glyptotherium) suggested either aquatic habitat or a high fermentation rate. Vizcaino et al. 2011 suggested that given the estimated low metabolic rate of Xenarthans but the relatively complex teeth of cingulates compared to sloths, that sloths have higher fermentation in digestive tract than glyptodonts. These animals were likely hindgut and likely hingut colon, since there are no large mammals that use caecums
Substrate.Notes: Gillette and Ray (1981) argued, based on co-occurrence with fossil capybaras, that these were aquatic grazers. However, biomechanic evidence suggets their feet were too small (Fariña 2005)
Other.Notes: open areas near springs (Perez-Crespo et al. 2012)

Foot.Type.Source.Formatted: Superina and Loughry 2011 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred: methods unclear but is a likely possibility
Fermentation.Type.Notes: The extant relatives, armadillos, are insectivores and have simple sac stomachs. Some have suggested the same for glyptodonts (Bocherens et al. 2017), but how they could sustain their metabolism as herbivores without fermentation seems dubious. Bocherens et al. 2017 found that their isotopic values (for Doedicurus spp, Glyptodon spp, Glyptotherium) suggested either aquatic habitat or a high fermentation rate. Vizcaino et al. 2011 suggested that given the estimated low metabolic rate of Xenarthans but the relatively complex teeth of cingulates compared to sloths, that sloths have higher fermentation in digestive tract than glyptodonts. These animals were likely hindgut and likely hingut colon, since there are no large mammals that use caecums
